DATE of DATE was passed , section CARDINAL of which provides ... In the judgment under appeal ( no . CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW provides :

“ Employees subject to the provisions of Legislative Decree no . DATE ... who receive a DATE salary are not entitled to the aforementioned family benefits if and for so long as they are receiving from their employer DATE pursuant to statute , a collective agreement , an arbitration award , company regulations or any other provision ... –benefit for dependent children exceeding the amount of benefit paid by the ORG ... ”

“ ( CARDINAL ) ORG and employees’ contributions to the ORG ... constitute welfare deductions for the benefit of the aforementioned bodies , which perform a welfare role , and the contributions shall continue to be payable notwithstanding any entitlement of beneficiaries who are employees to similar benefit from their employers or other institutions .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG enacted a law ( no . DATE ) entitled “ rules on the special tax on the consumption of petroleum products and other provisions ” . Section CARDINAL of that PERSON provides :

“ ( CARDINAL ) ORG and employees’ contributions in the insurance branches under the responsibility of the ORG ... shall be deemed to be welfare deductions for the benefit of those bodies and shall be payable notwithstanding any entitlement of the insured to similar benefits from their employers or other institutions .

( CARDINAL ) No claims shall be made for repayment of contributions referred to in the preceding paragraph that have been paid to the ORG ... before publication of this PERSON and any claim relating to such contributions shall be extinguished and any claim pending in any court for the repayment of such contributions shall be struck out .

It was indicated in the explanatory report that the purpose of the provision was to settle the issue whether contributions to the ORG ( in particular those relating to benefit for dependent children ) were “ welfare deductions ” , that is to say contributions payable by those liable to make them even where the risk covered by the insurance would never materialise .

CARDINAL . In CARDINAL judgments of DATE ( no . DATE ) and CARDINAL DATE ( no . DATE ) , respectively concerning disputes between ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) and its employees and ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) and its employees , ORG clarified the meaning of section CARDINAL of Law no . DATE and especially of the words “ continue to be payable ” contained in section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) . At the same time it upheld the decisions of the courts below in which the ORG and the ORG had been ordered to pay compensation to some of their employees for the deductions from their salaries made for the benefit of the ORG .
More particularly , in its judgment of DATE , ORG said :

It is apparent from the aforementioned provisions and from the fact that ORG staff are entitled to a ORG pension and to medical cover ... , that it is inconceivable and not intended by the legislature that staff should receive additional cover from the ORG for unemployment benefit and family benefit ... Before PERSON no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL was adopted and as the full court of ORG held in its judgment no . CARDINAL , the ORG ’s employees had no obligation under the PERSON to make contributions to the ORG ; section CARDINAL of the aforementioned Law – as indicated by the words ‘ continue to be payable’ DATE does not impose any such obligation on employees . Consequently , that section does not apply where there is no obligation to make contributions , which is the position with the ORG ’s staff ... ”

In its judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG said that no obligation to make contributions was created by the entry into force of section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL , as it was provided that the contributions continued to be payable , which meant that where no contributions had been payable previously , the aforementioned PERSON did not create such an obligation .
